So I'm a bit torn. I love that my neovim config is incredibly portable, fast, and accessible. But I love that VSCode just sorta works.

But then, I just went ahead and redid my entire VSCode keymaps config. With a carefully planned mapping scheme, I was able to re-create every navigational benefit neovim has. Sure, it's slower. But there's no learning curve.
I got almost all the niceties from VSCode, with none of the sluggishness. I do miss just ALT+Clicking on any method and jumping to its definition. But there are ways around that.

I got suckered into trying neovim again by @ThePrimeagen. After spending too much time on an over-engineered config, I used it exclusively for a week. I added which-key.nvim to help me over the navigation learning curve. But after a few days, I really was BLAZINGLY faster.

@stolinski @wesbos  Y'all busy people and this might be a stretch but what the hell. Any tips on how to better handle 150k - 250k pages with @gatsbyjs?

Some context:
Data File (JSON) > Template.js > Static Page

Each data file is unique and requires it's own static page.

There's a query done with each page render, so that does increase build times. But each data file is a single clients info. Think bio pages. Data files are created from API calls to a server (separate app handling that).

Whole process is able to change; nothing is set in stone.
